Question: To what extent do relevant laws, regulations, policies and guidance provide a basis for collecting and publishing structured data on government procurement?
Existence
Are there any laws, policies or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?
Option1: They are in draft, or are not yet implemented
Supporting0: 1;Please provide brief details

Question: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations or guidance discuss collection and publication of structured and open data?
Option0: Relevant laws, policies and guidance explicitly create barriers to collecting and publishing structured data
Option1: There is no mention of data in the relevant laws, policies or guidance
Option2: Requirements to collect data are set out in relevant non-binding policy or guidance
Option3: Requirements to collect data are set out in relevant binding policy, regulations or law
Option4: Requirements to publish data are set out in relevant non-binding policy or guidance
Option5: Requirements to publish data are set out in relevant binding policy or law
Supporting0: 0;Please briefly detail the barriers created (e.g. requirements for paper-based filing only)

Question: Elements
Part 1: What kinds of procurement process does the framework cover?
Requirements for data collection and/or disclosure apply to goods and services
Supporting0: 1,2;If there is a threshold value below which disclosure requirements do not apply, please provide the currency and value here (E.g. USD 10000)

Question: Requirements for data collection and/or disclosure apply to public works contracts
Supporting0: 1,2;If there is a threshold value below which disclosure requirements do not apply, please provide the currency and value here (E.g. USD 10000)

Question: Requirements for data collection and/or disclosure apply equally to direct awards and specialised procurement procedures
OptionGuidance: Answer partially if there are weaker data collection and transparency requirements for direct awards or specialised procurement procedures.
Supporting0: 1,2;If there is a threshold value below which disclosure requirements do not apply, please provide the currency and value here (E.g. USD 10000)

Question: Part 2: What stages of the procurement process does the framework cover?
The planning phase is covered
The tender stage is covered
The award stage is covered
Contract spending and performance is covered
Part 3: What does the framework say specifically about data?
The rules/guidance support publication of open data.
The rules/guidance supports collection of structured data.
The rules/guidance requires timely updates to data
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards
Supporting0: 1,2;Are they international standards?
Supporting1: 1,2;Please list significant data standards mentioned in the rules/guidance

Question: Extent
How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed for this question?
Option0: They only apply in a narrow set of situations
Option1: They cover one or more central government agencies, but there are many agencies or local government units with weaker rules/guidance
Option2: They cover one or more central government agencies, but there are similar rules/guidance that apply to many other agencies and/or local government units.
Option3: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national and local government
Supporting0: 0;When do these rules/guidance apply?
Supporting1: 1,2;Which agency or agencies do these rules/guidances apply to?
Supporting2: 3;Are there any notable exceptions? (E.g. defence sector)

Question: To what extent is detailed structured data on public procurement processes available as open data?
Existence
Is this data available online in any form?
Option1: Data is available, but not as a result of government action
Option2: Data is available from government, or because of government actions
Supporting0: 0;Are there other offline ways to access this data in the country? (e.g. attending an office to inspect it)
Supporting1: 1;If government is not providing access to data, how is this data available?
Supporting2: 1,2;Please provide a URL for where this data can be found

Question: Elements
Part 1: How open is the dataset?
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
Supporting0: 1,2;Please provide a URL where this machine-readable data can be found. (Additional URLs can be included in the justification and supporting evidence)
Supporting1: 1,2;Please provide a comma separated list of the formats available? (E.g. csv, json)
Supporting2: 1;What prevents you from assessing this data as fully machine-readable?

Question: The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole
OptionGuidance: Answer no if it's only possible to access individual records; Answer partially if it's possible to export extracts of the data; Answer yes if there are bulk downloads or APIs providing access to the whole dataset without financial, technical or legal barriers.
Supporting0: 1,2;Please provide a URL where bulk download access is available or described.
Supporting1: 1,2;If bulk access is provided through an API, please provide a link to where the API is described.

Question: Data is openly licensed.
Supporting0: 0;If there are explicit restrictions placed on re-use of the dataset, briefly describe those here.
Supporting1: 1,2;If the data is provided with an explicit open license, please provide the name of the license, or a link to it here.

Question: Data is timely and updated.
Supporting0: When was the most recent update to this dataset?

Question: The agency responsible for providing this information offers an accessible web tool to make simple queries and explore available information without requiring advanced data skills.
Supporting0: 1,2;Please provide URL
Supporting1: 1;What are the main barriers to accessibility and usability?

Question: Part 2: What kinds of procurement, and stages of the procurement process does the dataset cover?
Procurement related to goods and services is included
Procurement related to public works is included
The planning phase is covered
The tender stage is covered
The award stage is covered
Contract spending and performance is covered
Data on past procurements is kept
Part 3: Which fields does the dataset contain?
The data contains names and unique identifiers for companies awarded contracts
The data contains start and end dates for tender processes and/or contracts
The data contains, or can be linked to, information on spending against the contract
The data contains a description of the goods, services or works being procured
The data contains identifiers or other features that connect together data on each stage of a single procurement process
The data is published according to one or more relevant data standards
Supporting0: 1,2;Which standards are in use?

Question: Extent
How comprehensive is the data assessed for this question?
Option0: The data assessed covers a very limited number of public procurements, and few other sources of data are available.
Option1: The data assessed covers, or is representative of the data available for, a significant number of public procurements, but there are large gaps in coverage
Option2: The data assessed covers, or is representative of the data available for, a large proportion of public procurement, but some gaps in coverage exist.
Option3: The data assessed covers, or is representative of the data available for, almost all public procurement.
Supporting0: 0;Please briefly describe the nature of the procurements the data covers
Supporting1: 1,2,3;Please briefly describe any notable gaps in coverage

Question: To what extent is there evidence of government applying data analytics to improve procurement practice?
Existence
To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
Option0: There is no evidence of this use
Option1: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects
Option2: There is evidence of multiple different uses involving different organisations
Option3: There is evidence that these uses are widespread, regular and embedded

Question: Elements
Part 1:
There is evidence of the government using data-driven procurement dashboards
Supporting0: 1,2;If dashboards are public, please provide the URL of an example dashboard page.

Question: There is evidence of the government carrying out red flag analysis
Supporting0: 1,2;If there are public online tools used by government to perform red flag analysis, please provide the URL of an example.

Question: There is evidence of government using analytics to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalised groups
Supporting0: 1,2;Please briefly list any marginalised groups addressed (e.g. women; indigenous owned businesses etc.)

Question: There is evidence of government using analytics to support sustainable / environmental procurement
Supporting0: 1,2;Please provide a with details

Question: Part 2:
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data
Extent
There is evidence that these uses are having meaningful positive impacts
